Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Ethnographic field study of engineering knowledge systems: Developing a social-process-centric situated model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project conducted by Oregon State University will advance the development of a social-process-centric situated model of engineering knowledge systems by a studying a group of NASA researchers as they develop the design of the BioSentinel nano satellite. This satellite will measure the effects of radiation in space on living organisms and will be the first biosensor operated remotely in space. The complexity and unprecedented nature of the BioSentinel project provides a unique opportunity to study how a team of engineers negotiates conflicting and competing demands in the highly restricted size, weight, and power capacity of a nano satellite package. Understanding the knowledge systems of engineer practitioners and how they communicate across differences is crucial to the development of an engineering curriculum that aligns more closely to actual engineering practice. The Bio Sentinel project will bring together individuals with expertise in genetic engineering, optics, microfluidics, control systems, communications, solar and battery power, propulsion, guidance and navigation systems, radiation physics, robotics, software and user interface, and thermal regulation. This group of engineers will be convened together for concentrated period of time in a single location working against strict deadlines. The Bio Sentinel design offers a unique opportunity to study how engineering expertise is actually applied and to document the social processes by which engineers with competing knowledge claims interact, reach consensus, and create a complex technological system. Understanding the processes by which engineers effectively communicate across differences helps to reframe engineering knowledge as a social, situated practice and will help to create an engineering education curriculum that is relevant to the workplace demands of creating complex technological systems.

The Oregon State team will structure this field study as an epistemological ethnography. This will be an immersive, participatory observation protocol designed to capture reliable and valid evidence of a group's knowledge practices. The project design recognizes that a significant recent shift in cognitive and learning sciences has been the move from individual-centric cognitive models of cognition to social-process-centric situative models. There is evidence that context and particularly, exactly the social, human context that is so often intentionally removed from studies, classrooms, and textbooks plays a vitally important role in what a person can be said to know. Situative models shift the focus from the students' knowledge and skills to their actions in specific social systems. To understand how and what STEM students need to know, data must be derived from social the processes surrounding the application of this knowledge in workplace environments. Study of the BioSentinel design will combine leading-edge theories of learning and cognition with engineering knowledge and social science research methods to simultaneously apply and develop an understanding of engineering knowledge systems as applied in an exceptionally complex and open-ended technological system design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project consisted of an observation and analysis of a design review meeting at NASA AMES Research Center.  Our interest in observing this design review was in better understanding how engineers share their expertise and knowledge in large complex projects.  This project was particularly interesting because it involved such a wide range of sciences (from DNA to deep-space navigation) and because the design review meeting provided such an unusual opportunity to meet all of the engineers involved and hear them all defend their designs in a single location and time.  This work is important because it will help us improve the ways we teach engineers and prepare students to enter engineering careers. 

This work is innovative in the way it adopts cutting edge social science approaches to persistent questions about how best to prepare students to become engineers.  Education and engineering are social practices – they are things people do in groups according to complex and complexly communicated social norms, values and expectations.  A great challenge to improving engineering education is that it requires expertise in engineering content as well as expertise in studying social systems.  This work seeks to close this gap by developing researchers and a research community that is sufficiently fluent in both the arenas of engineering and social practices.   

Engineering is obviously important to society because of the technologies and systems we all rely on to live our lives, but there is also a subtler way engineering and engineering practice are important to society.  For more than a hundred years land-grant universities have sought to serve their communities by offering access to “practical education” that would allow individuals to pursue more rewarding and socially beneficial careers, particularly in agriculture, science and engineering.  The idea is that a worker educated at a university benefit society directly through their work, and society additionally benefits when more citizens have access to higher-paying and more stable careers.  In this way, the university system is an essential pathway for pursuing the class mobility and self-actualization promised by the American dream.
